subject: RE: [junit] Is coverage important?  RE: Test Coverage Analysis To ol For Junit
msgSnippet: Is coverage really that important?  The directive is to Test everything that could possibly break , not Test everything . Unit Tests give you great benefits
messageBody:
RE: [junit] RE: Test Coverage Analysis Tool For Junit
Is coverage really that important?  The directive is to "Test everything that could possibly break", not "Test everything".
 
Unit Tests give you great benefits in productivity and quality.  I have worked on XP teams that measured both quality and productivity.  Unit Testing and XP does improve both!  However, there comes a point where more Unit Tests only marginally increases quality while not increasing productivity (even negatively impacting productivity).  Developers should question the value of creating more Unit Tests.  If you are not careful, you can get into a "Test everything" mode and kill productivity.
 
Since Coverage metrics can lead the team to focus on "Test Everything", it isn't a great measurement.  Instead, focus on "things that could break" and you will continue to gain both increased productivity and quality.   Only use Coverage tools to reveal something that could break.  Using coverage as a metric is a poor practice.  I suggest using quality metrics instead (i.e. number of Unit Tests and number of passing Functional Tests)
 
- Greg Houston
www.ISS.net
